entry.title: Change
entry.content:
What is change?‚Ä¶

To me, anything different is change.

This brings us to the next question‚Ä¶

Do you like it?‚Ä¶

At the first instinct, I don‚Äôt like it‚Ä¶ (here I don‚Äôt include clothes and food coz I love those changes üòâ)

So do you like it afterwards?‚Ä¶

Well, this depends on the change itself. If I can adapt to it quickly then yes, I like it but if I have to make an effort then it takes a while to like it and even after that, sometimes I don‚Äôt like it.

So why do you not like it?‚Ä¶

That is simple because I think it is not good for me.. If I feel it is good then I like it but I feel otherwise I don‚Äôt like it.

Wooh that‚Äôs a lot of liking in this blog‚Ä¶.

Hmm well lot of liking is better than disliking right????????

That‚Äôs the whole point.. If we get it and start liking stuff then things will be better

And how does it relate to your work at LINZ?

You always have to break my bubble‚Ä¶ üòí
Well it has all the relation to it and not just to LINZ but to every organisation.
And more so for organisations that have people working with them for a long long time.

A motivation to change in business is competition. If you don‚Äôt cope up with it then somewhere deep down you know that it‚Äôs going to fail sooner or later.

So what is different in Government?‚Ä¶

Well nothing much except the fact that you don‚Äôt have any competition and that you have people who have been working there for ages and are used to things being ‚Äútheir‚Äù way that they don‚Äôt want to change anymore.

So what happens to people who like change in government?‚Ä¶

Some people stay there and keep pushing however, many of them, after a lot of pushing around here and there and not getting things done, eventually leave.
So the result is a filtered accumulation of people who don‚Äôt want to change.

So what do you think can be done to change the situation?‚Ä¶

Hmm that‚Äôs a good question‚Ä¶ but the answer is straightforward. If people stop focusing on what they are losing and focus more on what they are gaining then this situation will sort itself out‚Ä¶

Easier said than done, give me a tangible way to do this.

I think the day everything starts linking back to PERFORMANCE, this problem will be solved automatically.
Private sector needs to keep up with change to survive the competition and make profit. Government needs to keep up with change to sustain & improve. Individuals need to keep up with change to keep performing.

So, you just are just validating what Darwin said years ago?‚Ä¶.

Yep, I am just confirming what we have all known for years.
Change is an inherent part of the process of evolution and growth. If we understand this and make small changes at a time, we will be winners. If we oppose it, then we keep piling up a whole lot of things that need to be changed, and changing a whole lot of things at once won‚Äôt be easy for us anymore.

And that‚Äôs where I sign off today‚Ä¶ more on performance next time üòä
entry.summary:
What is change?‚Ä¶

To me, anythin

entry.title: Ambition
entry.content:
Ambition

Ambition is an interesting topic.

If you think about it, anything notable was likely classed as ambitious as one point.

Whether it‚Äôs products, companies or ideas, there were two likely outcomes.

Some things were ambitious, but ultimately, achievable while others were perhaps overly ambitious and failed.

No matter how you look at it, both types still took a lot of courage, and it wasn‚Äôt easy, right?

Perhaps they were before their time or maybe the execution was a little off. There‚Äôs still something to be learned from both types of attempts.

My point is that being ambitious isn‚Äôt easy but it‚Äôs better than not trying, right?

What does this have to do with Code for Aotearoa?

So without sugar coating it, we basically want to make a set of tools.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing wrong with that?‚Äù, you might be saying and you‚Äôre definitely right!

I think it just feels like it would be easier to get your average citizen more excited by showing them a shiny, interactive web app than some back end tools that wouldn‚Äôt be as tangible.

I know if I tried to pitch a tool to myself, I‚Äôd take the web app anyday but now we‚Äôre on the other end of that decision and it‚Äôs definitely not fun, haha!

Such tools would also have to be more ambitious seeing as we‚Äôd hope to make them easily adaptable by other departments if they liked the look of them.

Is that achievable in 3 months?

Well, that‚Äôs the thing, right? It‚Äôs a three month pilot program so we don‚Äôt want to promise the world but we do at least want to start something that someone else can pick up once we‚Äôre done.

We didn‚Äôt have the luxury of knowing LINZ in depth before hand but now for anyone that follows on with our work, we can brief them, both verbally and with documents, on where LINZ is at, what projects are underway and myriad of other things like ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs geospatial?‚Äù

Now, while we‚Äôve definitely learnt a lot, finding that niche where we can build something is the tough part. We‚Äôre slowly making progress towards where we want to be but unfortunately, these things can take time to get everyone on board.

Wrap up time?

Yeah, so those were just some of my thoughts about what‚Äôs been going on.

If you‚Äôve been wondering about why we‚Äôve been mostly quiet, there just hasn‚Äôt been anything hugely notable we can point to but we‚Äôll get there in time.

During the first few weeks, it also felt like every idea we came up with was either not a viable fit or was already being worked on by bigger teams, or even companies of higher skilled people than outselves!

Anywho, we‚Äôll keep on being ambitious and trying to create something that will be useful, hopefully for a long period of time.
entry.summary:
Ambition

Ambition is an interesting topic.

If yo

entry.title: Hydrography, or Hey Pal, Stop Launching Missiles From Our Ocean
entry.content:
Hey, you look kinda tired? Doing alright there?

Oh, me? Yeah, I‚Äôve just had my brain overloaded with all the wonderous services provided by Land Information New Zealand

Title card drops from the ceiling

This is a blog post, not a TV show‚Ä¶

Oops, wrong format, haha! So, I heard you‚Äôve started off on this whole Code for Aotearoa business? What‚Äôs the deal with that?

So! Before we talk about Code for Aotearoa, let‚Äôs learn about Code for All.

Ah, the ol‚Äô bait and switch?

Shush, this is my blog and I‚Äôll write it however I feel like!

ahem

Once upon a time, well, no actually instead of retreading old ground, I‚Äôll just refer you over to the post that Pete wrote last week.

Cheater

Well, it‚Äôs more efficient I reckon. So, how about I tell you all about LINZ.

Whoa there pal, we‚Äôve just started! Maybe take it easy and just tell me one cool thing you learned

Hmm, yeah, considering this post is already half a week late, you‚Äôre probably right. Weird, it‚Äôs like you can almost read my mind.

Anyway, how do you feel about Hydrography?

Hydrowhat?

Hydrography!

The study of water bodies, like lakes, rivers and even the ocean.

It‚Äôs such a cool word, huh? Just kinda feels nice to say

What‚Äôs cool about water?

The temperature

ba dum tiss

No but they do a lot of interesting stuff. They‚Äôre responsible for mapping the sea. Without that information, you‚Äôd have people unaware of the depths and shallows which means a lot of beached ships.

They also are in charge of the NAVAREA alerts. Psst, ask me ‚ÄúWhat are NAVAREA alerts? It looks good when you do the big text‚Äù

What are NAVAREA alerts? It looks good when you do the big text

Oh, I put my ending quote mark in the wrong place, oops.

NAVAREAs are basically specific areas that get assigned to a government where it becomes their job to issue warnings for things like weather warnings, loose icebergs and missile launches.

Missile? Excuse me?

Yup, there have been a few cases where foreign countries have conducted missile launches in the oceans administered by LINZ.

Generally they‚Äôll receive an email and if the warning is considered notable then within the short time of 2 hours, the following will happen:

  • The team will generate a small piece of text, intended to be beamed out to mariners
  • That message is sent to Kordia who will also record a voice over to accompany the text
  • Both are beamed up to a satellite where the message is redirected down towards our oceans so that mariners are able to receive the broadcast on their radios and other equipment

Wow, that‚Äôs actually really interesting

I told you! Keep in mind though that while there are recreational mariners, it‚Äôs the big commercial trawlers and what not who get the most use out of the broadcasts.

Well, that said, there‚Äôs actually a lot of things they‚Äôre required to carry under law but that‚Äôs a different story.

Hopefully you found this all as facinating as I did!

Until next week which, well, actually is just this week so double blog posts since mine was so late, haha.

The first week was all pretty hectic but hopefully we should be able to pick up the slack a bit and get lots of good tweets and that going on!

entry.title: The World Called LINZ
entry.content:
Land Information New Zealand or Toit≈´ Te Whenua, popularly known as LINZ, is the government agency responsible for making regulations that govern our land.

LINZ is also the organisation that has pioneered the push for open data in New Zealand, which they are currently at the forefront of.

So who am I?

Well, dear reader, I‚Äôm Vaishnavi - a software developer who along with my other developer friends - Marcus, Pete and Gabby, have joined a pilot program called Code For Aotearoa. We strongly believe that the keyboard is mightier than the sword and that we are here to change the world.

What is this Code for Aotearoa now?

Code for Aotearoa is a pilot to open new ways through which we cam make meaningful contributions to government.

8th September 2016‚Ä¶ the day my world collided with these two other dimensions - Code for Aotearoa and LINZ‚Ä¶

The first week at LINZ went by really quick‚Ä¶ I had the opportunity to meet a lot of amazing people who have a wealth of knowledge. Just meeting so many interesting people would have been a task in itself, let alone being able to get an insight into their work.

Like any organisation of people, there‚Äôs‚Ä¶ a wide range of personalities. Some welcoming and others‚Ä¶ could do with a bit of work but perhaps they‚Äôll warm up to us in time. Each meeting has been a learning experience, that‚Äôs for sure!

So many meetings and a boatload of new information,

Both me and Marcus have the daunting task of assimilating the information and then start the second phase of interviews‚Ä¶

As for LINZ, I can say that they have done a great job of releasing heaps of data, which has made it challenging for us to add value to their current offerings.

That said, competition is what drives innovation and since that doesn‚Äôt apply to LINZ, we hope to instill a bit of friendly competition with the people we meet.

As for solutions, identifying the pain points of their immediate customers would definitely be a good start.

Until next week this has been Vai signing off‚Ä¶
entry.summary: Land Information New Zealand or Toit≈´ Te Whenua, popularly known as LIN
